title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: L.A. Megamansion "The One" Falls Into Bankruptcy; Neiman Marcus Sales Rebound Post-Chapter 11
text:
Nile Niami, developer of ‘The One,' at his Beverly Hills home in 2018.

L.A. megamansion "The One" slips into chapter 11. The bankruptcy filing pauses a planned foreclosure sale for the megamansion once listed for $500 million. A company formed by developer Nile Niami hopes to find a buyer by running an alternative chapter 11 sale process for the palatial property.

Neiman Marcus says sales are up. The luxury department-store operator, a year after filing chapter 11, told its bondholers that its sales are up from 2019 levels at its 44 physical stores and online. The results continue Neiman's turnaround from deep losses last year brought on by the Covid-19 pandemic.

Bankruptcy

Hertz said Teslas would be available for Uber drivers by 2023.

Hertz strikes deal with Uber. Continuing its eventful week, Hertz Global Holdings Inc. said it has a deal to make up to 50,000 Tesla's available to Uber drivers by 2023. The deal with Uber builds on Hertz efforts to boost momentum for its rental car business post-bankruptcy.

Argo Tea owner files for bankruptcy. Golden Fleece Beverages Inc., which does business as Argo Tea, has filed for bankruptcy, saying it is "essentially on death's door."

Directors of the Chicago-based business, which sought protection from creditors Wednesday, include former Walgreens Chief Executive Officer Greg Wasson.

In early 2020, Golden Fleece took ownership of what had already been a struggling Argo Tea brand, pursued by creditors. After the pandemic began, company-owned cafés were transitioned to licensees, closed permanently or sold. Golden Fleece contracts out all tea manufacturing.

The company has liabilities of roughly $1.6 million. It generates most revenues by selling its products to customers that include Walgreens. It said an internal inquiry is underway regarding two pandemic aid loans it received from the government.

—Becky Yerak

Goldman Sachs can't stop lawsuit. An effort by Goldman Sachs Group Inc. to get a Delaware bankruptcy judge to stop a lawsuit filed against the investment bank in Tennessee has failed.

As part of the 2020 bankruptcy of restaurant chain Ruby Tuesday Inc., Goldman Sachs got ownership of a corporate retreat at Maryville College in Tennessee. Goldman Sachs was then sued by BNA Associates LLC, which alleged that Goldman Sachs had interfered with its earlier efforts to take over the property.

Goldman Sachs then asked the bankruptcy court that had approved Ruby Tuesday's restructuring earlier this year to essentially require BNA Associates to dismiss its complaint.

On Wednesday, Judge John Dorsey denied Goldman's request, saying, among other things, that his approval of the Ruby Tuesday bankruptcy plan doesn't have the effect of barring the Tennessee lawsuit.

—Becky Yerak

CalPlant ups bankruptcy financing. CalPlant I LLC won final court approval for a bigger bankruptcy financing package, an increase to $37.4 million from $30.1 million.

The fiberboard manufacturer, which has a Northern California facility that converts rice-farming waste into a wood substitute, told the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., on Wednesday that it needs more financing partly due to rising commodity prices.

Its new budget reflects rising resin and wax costs. CalPlant, which filed for chapter 11 earlier this month, told the court that more financing was also needed to cover rising insurance premiums and higher capital expenditures.

—Becky Yerak
